Package io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost

Interface StochasticModel

All Superinterfaces:
InHostConfiguration, Serializable
@Immutable public interface StochasticModel extends InHostConfiguration
Parameters for a stochastic in‑host viral dynamics model.

This interface defines the numerical inputs and distributions used to initialise the discrete stochastic in‑host model implemented by InHostStochasticState. Values here are sampled by the default initialiser DefaultInHostStochasticStateInitialiser to construct an initial InHostStochasticState for each infected individual. The parameters control initial pool sizes, immune capacity and activation dynamics, rates of viral replication and infection, and the calibration cutoff for what constitutes a disease‑level viral load.

Keep descriptions concise: the initialiser samples distributional entries (see methods returning Distribution) and copies scalar parameters directly into the initial in‑host state. Downstream updates are performed by InHostStochasticState.update(Sampler,double,double) which uses these initial values to govern stochastic transitions.

Author:
Rob Challen

  • Field Details

    • DEFAULT

      static final io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost.ImmutableStochasticModel DEFAULT
      A sensible default configuration for the stochastic in‑host model.

      This instance provides default distributions and scalars used in examples and tests. The DefaultInHostStochasticStateInitialiser will sample the distributional entries from this object when creating a fresh InHostStochasticState.

  • Method Details

    • getBaselineViralInfectionRate

      Double getBaselineViralInfectionRate()
      Baseline per‑virion infection rate used to calibrate the infection probability.

      The scalar is copied into the initial in‑host state. It is converted into a per‑time‑step probability during updates and therefore directly affects how readily virions convert susceptible targets into exposed cells in InHostStochasticState.update(Sampler, double, double).

      Returns:
      baseline viral infection rate (scalar)

    • getBaselineViralReplicationRate

      Double getBaselineViralReplicationRate()
      Baseline viral replication rate used to determine virion production.

      This scalar sets the expected production per infected cell and is sampled/copied by the initialiser into the host state. Larger values increase the expected Poisson rate of new virions produced each step, driving faster viral load growth.

      Returns:
      baseline viral replication rate (scalar)

    • getImmuneActivationRate

      Distribution getImmuneActivationRate()
      Distribution for the immune activation (priming) rate.

      This distribution is sampled by the initialiser to set the host's propensity to prime immune cells in response to exposed or infected targets. A higher sampled value leads to faster priming and earlier immune activity during InHostStochasticState.update.

      Returns:
      a distribution for immune priming rates

    • getImmuneTargetRatio

      Distribution getImmuneTargetRatio()
      Distribution for the immune to target cell ratio.

      The initialiser samples this distribution to set the starting total immune count via floor(targets * ratio). This controls immune capacity relative to target cells and influences neutralisation and clearance probabilities in subsequent stochastic updates.

      Returns:
      a distribution producing immune:target ratios used at initialisation

    • getImmuneWaningRate

      Distribution getImmuneWaningRate()
      Distribution for the waning rate of active immune cells.

      The initialiser samples this entry to determine how quickly active effectors transition to senescent states. Faster waning reduces long‑ term immune activity and can increase susceptibility to reinfection in the simulation.

      Returns:
      a distribution for immune waning rates

    • getInfectionCarrierProbability

      Distribution getInfectionCarrierProbability()
      Distribution giving the probability an exposed cell becomes a chronic carrier.

      Sampled at initialisation, this controls the per‑cell probability that an exposed target will evade clearance and enter a persistent reservoir. Even if the default is zero, non‑zero values alter long‑term infection dynamics and the pool of targets available for future replication.

      Returns:
      a distribution for chronic infection carrier probability

    • getTargetCellCount

      Integer getTargetCellCount()
      Total number of target cells modelled for a single host.

      The initialiser places this value into the created InHostStochasticState as both the total target pool and the initial susceptible pool. It therefore sets the scale of the infection: larger pools reduce per‑cell exposure for a given number of virions and change the saturation behaviour in the coverage calculations used during infection updates.

      Returns:
      the initial total target cell count

    • getTargetRecoveryRate

      Distribution getTargetRecoveryRate()
      Distribution for the target cell recovery (regeneration) rate.

      The initialiser samples this distribution to set the baseline rate at which removed or damaged targets are replaced. Higher recovery rates replenish susceptible targets more quickly and can shorten the period of high severity in the in‑host simulation.

      Returns:
      a distribution for target recovery rates used at initialisation

    • getVirionsDiseaseCutoff

      Integer getVirionsDiseaseCutoff()
      Calibration parameter defining the unit of virions considered disease‑level.

      The initialiser stores this cutoff on the host state; it is used to normalise virion counts into a unitless viral load proxy and to scale external virion doses. Changing this value moves the threshold for when an individual's viral load is treated as clinically relevant in the simulation.

      Returns:
      the virion disease cutoff used for normalisation and dosing
